citation.article-title: Enterococcus raffinosus sp. nov., Enterococcus solitarius sp. nov. and Enterococcus pseudoavium sp. nov.

p.s: Description of Enterococcus raffinosus sp. nov.
Enterococcus raffinosus (raf'fi.no.sus. M.L. adj. raffinosus of raffinose, referring to ability to metabolize raffinose)
Cells are ovoid and occur mostly in pairs or short chains.
The cells are
Gram-positive and non-motile.
Catalase negative.
Growth occurs at 45°C and weakly if at all at 10°C.
Strains grow in 6.5% NaCl.
Facultatively anaerobic.
Acid is produced from L-arabinose, glycerol, lactose, mannose, mannitol, melibiose, raffinose, ribose, salicin, sorbose, sorbitol, sucrose and trehalose.
Acid is not produced from inulin and glycogen.
Some strains produce acid from amidon.
The type strain does not produce acid from amidon.
All strains are Voges-Proskauer positive and hydrolyse esculin; hippurate and starch are not hydrolysed.
Leucine arylamidase and pyrrolidonylarylamidase positive.
Urease arginine dehydrolase, α-galactosidase, β-galactosidase, β-glucuronidase and alkaline phosphatase negative.
Lancefield extracts of most strains react with group D antiserum.
Group A type peptidoglycan based upon lysine (type Lys-D-Asp).
The long-chain cellular fatty acids are of the straight-chain saturated, non-unsaturated and cyclopropane ring types.
The major components are tetradecanoic and hexadecanoic acids.
The G + C content of DNA ranges from 39 to 40 mol%, as determined by melting temperature.
The strains form a distinct homology group, as determined by DNA-DNA hybridization.
Isolated from human clinical sources.
The type strain is 1789/79 (= NCTC 12192).
